moves.1. c4: English opening. Please rate or type a message on this game.
moves.1... Nf6 2. Nc3 g6: Transposing into A King Indian Defense
moves.3. e4: I believe Nf3 would be stronger than e4. Playing the flank attack moves
moves.3... d6 4. d4 Bg7: The main line, also know as the Mar del Plata
moves.6... Nbd7: hhmm? Is not he suppose to play e5?
moves.7. O-O e5 8. d5: Petrosian System, one move behind though. Well because black played Nd7 instead of the orthodox e5. I restrict my opponent to any counter play by locking the pawn formation. This is very safe for white.
moves.8... Nc5: ?! not sure if this was good
moves.9. Qc2 Ne8: preparing the thematic f5 break. If you do not know King Indian Defense setups. Black plays to the king side and white plays the queen side.
moves.10. b4: The bayonet attack! b4 is the start of my expansion on the queen side. Ignoring blacks counter play on the king side.
moves.10... Na6 11. Rb1: hah! two birds with one stone. I protect the b pawn and get out of the a1-h8 diagonal if it becomes open. Watch my rooks in this game
moves.11... f5 12. a4: Continuing my annexation of my enemy's territory
moves.12... c5: ?! I think this is the start of his down fall. he is supposed to play king side. Nf6 double attacking my  e pawn would have been better or fxe opening the f file. Even f4 for black would be fine. Playing the king side
moves.13. dxc6 e.p. bxc6: Now I have a queen side pawn majority. Taking into account that he has a backward D pawn
moves.14. Rd1: Pointing my rook to his queen. Rooks belong on open files.
hah! preparing to pin his queen. This combination helps me win the game
moves.22. Bxa6: Now I am ahead in material. If played correctly I have a won game
I do not know if he seen this. He should have
moves.31. Rxg5 Qa2: After my second win of Material I decided to to liquidate the pieces on the board to a winning end game.
